newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resids mostly slip on ample supply.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resids mostly slip on ample supply.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel prices mostly lost ground Wednesday in quiet trade despite forecasts for colder weather next week, pressured by ample supplies and still-sluggish utility demand, industry sources said.
"Resid is a dog. There's more around than we need," said one cash trader, noting supplies were ample, gas was getting cheaper and there was little utility or industrial interest.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent slipped about a quarter to the $17.75 a barrel level, with March paper also talked slightly lower at $17.35-60 on weaker crude, traders said.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour notionally gained slightly to the $20.50 area but most agreed competitive East Coast city gate gas prices should cap further advances.
Traders said 10,000 barrels of prompt NYH 0.3 percent low pour sold at $21.75, unchanged on the day.
High sulphur in New York remained pressured by plentiful supply, with 2.2 percent down 25-50 cents to the $16.25 area.
At the U.S. Gulf, one percent held steady at $16.50, while three percent slid a quarter to $14.00-25. No USG deals were reported.
Traders said concerns about Star's refinery coker maintenance this month, which was pumping 50,000 bpd of extra HSFO, continued to weigh on the market.
New York city gate swing gas prices stayed little changed in the low-$3.00/mmBtu area. NYH one percent resid was at a $2.82/mmBtu equivalent.
